artillery.note: Artillery regiment with three battalions. Tiger tank from s.Pz.Abt. 501 attached.

soft_skin_vehicles.note: Reduced truck allocation due to supply constraints in Tunisia Campaign

supply_logistics.supply_status: CRITICAL - Severely constrained by Allied naval interdiction and air supremacy. Fuel at 4 days (marginal), ammunition adequate at 12 days, water critical for desert operations. Supply lines from Tunis port under constant air attack.
notes: Division arrived from France December 1942 with limited desert experience
Supply lines from Tunis under constant Allied air attack
Fuel shortages severely limiting mobility
Equipment wear from desert conditions

weather_environment.terrain_type: Mixed terrain - Coastal plain, mountainous passes (Kasserine), desert wadis. Cooler and wetter than Western Desert.
notes: Winter conditions in Tunisia mountainous terrain
Kasserine Pass operations in February
Desert wadis and coastal plain terrain
Allied air superiority limits daylight movement

subordinate_units.note: Future Field Marshal von Manteuffel commanded. Tiger from s.Pz.Abt. 501 attached as III. Abteilung.
Two battalions plus heavy weapons companies
Two battalions plus heavy weapons companies
Three battalions: I./II. Abteilung (105mm), III. Abteilung (150mm)
Mix of towed PaK 40/38 and Marder III self-propelled

tactical_doctrine.role: Mobile armored division for combined-arms offensive operations at Kasserine Pass. Arrived from France December 1942 for Tunisia Campaign. Partnered with 21st Panzer Division for offensive operations.
special_capabilities: Experienced panzer tactics from Eastern Front
Tiger tank attached (s.Pz.Abt. 501) provides exceptional firepower
known_issues: Lack of desert experience compared to Afrika Korps veterans
Fuel shortages severely limiting mobility (4 days reserve)
Allied air superiority prevents daylight movement
Equipment wear from desert conditions (sand, heat)
Supply lines from Tunis under constant air attack

historical_context.formation_date: 1939 (reformed from disbanded Kav.Div. in East Prussia)
major_battles: Battle of Sidi Bou Zid (14-15 February 1943): Major victory over US 1st Armored Division
Battle of Kasserine Pass (19-22 February 1943): Partnered with 21st Panzer, German tactical victory
Battle of El Guettar (23 March 1943): Repulsed by US 1st Infantry Division, German defeat
notes: Division arrived from France December 1942 with 155 tanks
Limited desert experience compared to Afrika Korps veterans
Panzer-Regiment 7 commanded by Oberst Hasso von Manteuffel (future Field Marshal)
Operations officer (Ia): Oberst Claus Schenk Graf von Stauffenberg (later attempted assassination of Hitler 20 July 1944)
Tiger tank from s.Pz.Abt. 501 attached as III./Panzer-Regiment 7
Partnered with 21st Panzer Division for Kasserine Pass offensive
70 tanks operational in Q1 1943 (midpoint between arrival and final surrender)
Final surrender: 12 May 1943, Tunisia

source: Nafziger Collection: German OOB reference 942GFGJ - 10. Panzer-Division Tunisia 1943

Cross-referenced: Commander von Broich, Stauffenberg as Ia confirmed
Cross-referenced: Panzer-Regiment 7 commanded by von Manteuffel
known_gaps: Exact tank strengths at Q1 start (interpolated from Dec 1942 arrival: 155 tanks, May 1943 final: 70 tanks)
Complete subordinate unit commander names (only Panzer-Regiment 7 confirmed)
Tessin Band 08 not accessed (10. Panzer-Division entry would provide additional detail)
notes: Q1 1943: Division in TUNISIA (Kasserine Pass offensive)
Arrived from France December 1942 with limited desert experience
Commander: Generalmajor Fritz Freiherr von Broich (from Feb 1943)
Operations officer: Oberst Stauffenberg (later attempted Hitler assassination)
Tank regiment: Commanded by future Field Marshal von Manteuffel
Major battles: Sidi Bou Zid (14-15 Feb), Kasserine Pass (19-22 Feb), El Guettar (23 March)
Partnered with 21st Panzer Division for offensive operations
Tier 2 classification due to estimated equipment and interpolated tank strengths
